div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE BRINDISI ROUTE.
div.p: "Of late," Soya the "Times of India," "the delays in the transit of the mails across the Continent have become incessant, and the frequent complaint* wo receive show that they are causing considerable irritation in India. The Peninsular and Oriental Company is not in any way responsible. That Company does. not. content to deliver the mails in Bombay on Friday morning, or at any other fixed time. It undertakes to deliver them in Bombay within a stipulated number of hours after receiving them at Brindisi, and it very rarely fails to fulfil its undertaking. Many people seem to regard it as a public grievance that the P. and O. Company does not drive its steamers faster when the mails are late. Every business man, at least, will perceive that that is not a business proposition. Why should the P. and O. Company incur increased expenditure and burn more coal to raise the speed of its ships, in order to atone for the shortcomings of the Continental railways? The Company does what it is asked to do, and what it contracts to do.; and in point of fact, by far the larger number of its mail deliveries within the year are considerably within contract time.

"The fault lies not with the steamship company, hut with the railways, and more particularly with the Italian lines. In spite of the repeated promise of the Italian Ministry, the trunk line down the Adriatic is still in a condition unworthy of a great mail routs.

So long AS so much uncertainty exist about the passage of the mails over the Alp, and through Italy, in winter we shall never be able to reckon upon a regular timing of the arrival of the moils at Bombay during the cold weather, when passengers are most numerous in business is briskest. It is a discreditable thing that while the transportation of the nails through the Mediterranean and the Red Sea and the Indian Ocean is punctually conducted, progressive Europe seems incapable of arranging for the regular running of its trains. This subject has been so long a matter for complaint that the desirability of considering the ultimate abandonment of the Brindisi route U clearly indicated."

div.head: MOSLEMS AND THE SULTAN.
div.p: A well-informed correspondent of the "Times of India" at Constantinople reports that the Sultan has recently had placed before him t letter from Bombay, which seems to have escaped the vigilance of his secret police. Copies of the letter, which is printed in Persian, have reached both the Grand Vizier and the Foreign Minister, and much consternation U the result, although there is not a word in the document which is not justified by actual facts. The correspondent has no doubt, from internal evidences, that the letter U what it professes to be, the work of some natives of India who have recently visited Turkey and seen for themselves the misgovernment rife throughout the Empire. The letter says that his supreme head of Islam his Majesty is held in veneration by nearly 200,000,000 Moslems in all parts of the world, and remarks that, had his policy been different, it would have been easy for him to unite all Moslems under his leadership for the mutual benefit of those of their co-religionists who lack freedom and education. The maladministration of the Empire was the cause of foreign interference, and his Majority energies were concentrated in endeavors to sow discord amongst European Powers, and so prevent their working in common to carry out those reforms which he himself should be the very first to introduce. Wherever the writers travelled in the Sultan's dominions they saw officials living by extortion, and their hearts bled at the sight of the Turkish soldiers starving and in rags. In consequence of their ill- treatment the troops now refused to fight against their co-religionists Yemen. Moslems throughout the world were ashamed that the chief Moslem State should be so lost to oil ideas of good government. Mention is mode of Germans being paid large salaries merely to attend the weekly Selamlik in the train of the Sultan, and of the vast sums squandered in the purchase of war material at the bidding' of the German Emperor. The Hedjaz Railway appears to the writers to be carried on set the present time, whatever it future benefit* to pilgrims may be, for the sole purpose of putting money into the pockets of the committee, with whom the patronage for contracts rests. The letter compare the freedom enjoyed under British rule in India with the tyranny existent in Turkey, and it is remarked that under the former the services of upright honest Mohamedans are readily obtainable. The correspondent doubts whether the letter will have any immediate good, as the members of his Majesty's entourage will not allow him to probe these ills and to see for himself how evil is the state of affairs. He believe? that wore the letter scattered broadcast throughout the whole Moslem world there would be a general uprising of Islam to demand reform.

div.p: A telegram from Jeddah states that the sanitary condition of the town is going from bad to worse. There were four deaths yesterday.

div.head: Austro-Hungarian Ball.
div.p: The committee at the Austro-Hungarian Benevolent Society informs us that, for the convenience of Ramleh residents, the Ramleh Railway Company will run two special trams after the ball, one at 2 a m. and the other at 3 a.m.

div.head: E. T. C
div.p: At the general meeting of the Eastern Tele graph Company, Limited, Sir John Wolfs- Barry stated that the company's Egyptian receipts for the last quarter of 1906 had shown an increase over the revenue before the redaction its rates.

div.head: Collapse of House.
div.p: Another house has collapsed in Cairo, this time is the Darb el Ahmar. Two children are killed and a woman saved. The total of Casualties in the past three days amounts to nine; four killed, five wounded. Can the Tanzim do nothing to check the repetition of these incidents?

div.head: Arab Museum's Acquisition.
div.p: The Arab Museum has just purchsed from Mr. Ralph Blanchard, the well known dealer in antiquities, a very .fine specimen of an Arabian mosque lamp, probably of late 14th century work, but as is well known it requires a considerable amount of study to fir the premier date. Mr. Blanchard was fortunate enough to find the lamp in London, but it now returns to i's former home. The lamp will be transfer d to the Arab Museum to-day.

div.head: Splendid Hotels Co.
div.p: The negotiations between the boards of the Splendid and Rift Hotels Companies forths purchase of the New Khedivial Hotel begin yesterday afternoon. The Ritz Company art disposing the matter on the basis of exchanging shares of one for the other company or the payment of £5 to each shareholder of the Splendid. It is rumored that the forthcoming general meeting of shareholders of the Splendid Hotels will only ratify the Bale on a basis of £6 per share.

div.head: In Japan.
div.p: The Japanese, having conquered by force of arms their tank amid the generations to retain their position as the most modern civilization. Thus they give themselves up to the study of the practical sciences, amongst others, to that of the living languages. The Berlitz School is going to establish soon a branch in that country. That school will certainly obtain the same success as its three hundred and forty predecessors. [ADVT]

div.head: THE RUSSIAN AFFAIR
THE CASE OF M GANVIET
div.p: The enquiry which is being held by the French unipolar authorities at Alexandria into the action of M. Raoul Ganviet, in reference to the recent disturbance at Alexandria, is still continuing The enquiry has been instituted in consequence of the complaints brought against that gentleman by the Egyptian Government, on behalf of the Alexandria City Polios, and by the Russian consular authorities at Alexandria. M. d'Abaza, the Russian Consul, formulated an official complaint sanctum. Canivet on the 27th nlto. and despatched it to M. Girard, the French Consul. In this document the Russian Consol complains of certain contents of "La Reforme" in the issue of that newspaper of Friday, the 18th inst.. M d'Abaza's grounds for complaint are the alleged falseness of the news dealing with the ironstones attending the arrest of the three men accused of plotting to blow up a Russian steamer by an infernal machine. The articles dealing with the matter were, in the opinion of the Russian consular authorities, tho cause of the popular outburst which culminated in the attack on the Russian steamer on Saturday, the 19-.h nlto., and the affray at the consulate on the following day. When the enquiry at the French Consulate is terminated it will be decided whether there are sufficient grounds according to French law for presenting.

A Cairo newspaper remarks : "How has it come about that the French consular authorities at Alexandria are engaged in presenting one of their own subjects who has only need the liberty which the law of the land recognizes belongs to each citizen How is it that a most grave trespass has been made on the most precious, the most imprescriptible of human rights ? Where can we discover the reasons for such a feeble line of policy! How can such an attitude be justified ? How can one explain the inexplicable?"

This criticism of the French Consul at Alexandria is quite beside the mark, as M. Girard bud to open an enquiry on the on Taint of the Russian Consul and the Egyptian Government, and it is ridiculous to criticize him This criticism of the French Consul at Alexandria is quite beside the mark, as M. Girard bud to open an enquiry on the on Taint of the Russian Consul and the Egyptian Government, and it is ridiculous to criticize him for doing what is his official duty.

div.head: FATHY BEY ZAGHOUL
div.p: "Al Watau" makes the following remarks on the subject of Fathy Bey Zaghoul's appointment :—

"It seems that the enemies of one country, who appear to imagine themselves its sole defenders, have not forgotten how to make mistakes. They are now beginning to attack one of the most independent, intelligent, and cultured Egyptians bounce it is reported that he is shortly to be appointed Under Secretary of State for Justice. We refer to Fathy Bey Zaghoul, an upright magistrate, an undaunted and energetic man, and above all a patriot. Bent Fathy Boy was a member of the special tribunal of Daoisbwais, but he followed the diotates of his conscious and the evidence set before him. He attack down the criminals, hot stroke with sorrow. What is there to criticize in this man I A magistrate cannot allow himself to yield to the demands or prejudices of parties. One of our confrère has not understood this and has been drawn into the vortex of insult and ignominy. Its calumnies and violence are absolutely nonratifiable."

div.head: SUEZ CANAL BOARD
BRITISH SHIPOWNERS AND LONDON COMMITTEE
div.p: The long standing dispute between British shipowners and the administration of the Suez Canal is to outcome up for farther discussion at the meeting of the Chamber of Shipping in London on Fob. 15.- At the instance of the Hull Chamber of Commerce and Shipping, the following resolution is to be brought forward : "That the attention of his Majesty's Government be called to the unsatisfactory composition-of the 'London Committee of the Suez Canal Company, and that the Government be repeatedly requested to name their ii flange to bring about an adequate representation open that committee of all classes of British shipping which make use of the canal." In substance, it is claimed, says the "Telegraph," that the London Committee of the Suez Canal inadequately represents the in terabits of the cargo carrying trade, aid that the basis on which its members are chosen is unsatisfactory.

Representations on the subject of reform in Suez Canal administration were made by the Chamber of Shipping to the late Government, . and an unfavorable reply was received from the Marquis of Lansdowne. It appears, however, that the president of the Chamber of Shipping vMr. Oswald Sanderson) has since had a private interview on the subject with | Sir Edward Grey and Mr. Lloyd-George, and | that the questions then raised are now receiving the attention of the Foreign Office and the Board of Trade.

div.head: OBITUARY
div.p: DR. VARENHORST PASHA.

We regret to report the death, which took plane at half, past one yesterday afternoon, of Dr. Vareuhprst Pasha, for forty-five years chief physician of the Deaooneese-i' Hospital, Alexandria. The funeral took place this afternoon, from the hospital, at four o'clock.

The late -Varenhorst Pasha was the son of a Protestant pastor who bad a living at A ok ride, near Ouabruok Hanuver. He studied medicine at Gottingen University ml came out to Alexandria in 1897 to work with his uncle, Dr. Shiedubaus, travelling by a tugboat which the Egyptian Government had ordered in Hodaud, Dr juruey taking five Weeks! On bus uncle's death, two years later, he enjoyed to his practice, and among other illustrious patients who sought his medical advice were Said Paths, I mail Pasha and Mohamed Tewfik Palma. On the 25th Raheb. 1275, he was appointed member of ihe General Board o Health aid among ether offices which be held were those of luspeo'.or of Vto-jiuation in Alexandria, chief physician of the Egyptian Hospital, member of the Quarantine Board, consulting physician, dean of the medical - faculty, and first ooaa inspector Alexandria, in which last capacity he took part on the | Municipal onion. On his retirement he was transferred to the said Municipality. Ha bad many Egyptian and foreign decorations ; the Red Eagle of Prussia, the Cross of Francis Joseph, the Medjidiah, Oimanieb, etc. He was honored with the Pashalik in 1885.

div.head: THE TRIPOLI FRONTIER.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has decided to send the Sub-Moudir of Behera and the major of Matrooh Markar to Benghazi with the object of asking the Montserrat of that district to take the necessary measures to suppress the frequent aggressions of the ' Benghazi Bedouins and prevent them attacking the Egyptian Bedouins living in their neighbourhood.

div.head: ITALIAN
"FAUST" AT THE ABBAS
div.p: " Dr. Faot's in town, or the Danger of Evil Companions"—alias Gounod's remine- scenes nf Goethe—forms a vivid and quaint con trust to Boito's Betting of the legend. Sig. Lucenti seized on every point of distinction and emphasized it even to ridicule. The average bass, one be assumes the conventional Mephistophelian clothes, gives one and the same interpretation of each version of the legend. In a word, Sig. Leonetti was splendid : he reveled in the part : he was the cynical captivation Bid Man,—"quite the gentleman" with a part, and, onoe in a way, the Fiend —under protest. Even in the dagger scene he was, so far as a qualified Fiend may so do, imitating the chorus, trying to use his sword as they lose their daggers ; and in the finale he just gave himself time-to spread his cloak, so that the boards should not soil his garments. His whole performance was internet with sarcasm, not against this world and the next, hot against Gounod's travesty of it. And his voice was asper: he only seemed to use half bio power, yet we never lost a note or an inflexion. In the garden scene, whatever the others did, be always kept the balance of sound. He was one careless — in the serenade—and just a shade off the note. Sig. Campanini was equally good, but not having so strong a sense of satire, he looked horribly bored. He had one real triumph—the encore of the soldiers' chorus. The horas, it is, were really excellent in that, but it was his conducting that gave the finish to the number. He gave up Signa. Isaia as hope- lens very soon. she was a most disappointing Marguerite : she began the jewel song prettily, but ended the ran with a jerk. She used far too rough tremolo, and her notes dragged. 8ig. Arrighetti wan in fine form as Valentine : he laugh with great power and accuracy. Signe. Qarsgnaui and Fronzi was quite passable as Marta and Siebel. Tb- sopranos were very bad in the chorus ; the men are excellent, and the reception of the soldiers' ch iron should encourage them. Sig. Battaui's old was more noticeable than ever : he was frontal high notes. H ought to b o a good rest. His voice seems to have gained in power, if one can judge fr-un the lower register!' and if only ho recovers he should be even better than he was in the Hummer. What a pity we could not base had Mile Divil y as Marguerite from the Khedivial Their .Iowa soprano of that quality would make the Abbas company about as good as such a company can be. At any rate Sig. Lichitin performance made he reputation memorable ; hut the im of the piece was almost too keen. I, for one. which he-irate before ever going again to "Front,'', after having seen him literally torn the part and tie drama inside out..

div.head: "CARMEN AT ZIZINIA"
div.p: "Carmen" was excellently given last night, nor could wo wish or expect to see a more vivacious or full-blooded heroine than Signs L via Berlendi, who has spared neither her pur-e nor her person to make this opera the ohief event of the Alexandria season ; her e iergy1s on tiring ado her frocks from Paris. For the first time we realized what an extraordinary compass of tone this lady wields, her contralto notes are clear and powerful without ever, as so often, amounting to a roar. The notice "House Fall" might well have been displayed whilst she was singing ''Sint an maims pas, je t'aime," or whatever it is in Italian, and here, en parentheses, we mast remark that this opera should be played in French) the translation communicates certain look of sharpness and conciseness to the rendering of the music.

In bus soft notes and his low notes 8ig. de Maroni (like the Wind of the Western Sea) showed to the greatest advantage, and, as always, adopted far better than any other member ot the caste. In the Toreador song we are sorry to say that Sig. Dalbore entirely missed his opportunity : he seemed afraid to let himself go, and, unless E-Camille does that, the number might as well be omitted altogether.

We found the orchestra thin and a little oratory, and would remind Sig. Zucoani, who took the overture much too fast, that we are quite satisfied to hear ' Carmen" given tamely in, and not against, time. The opera house is no place for the lowering of records, though we have, during the entr'acte, often wished that it were.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S. Orchis (Westcott and Laurence Line) left Malta yesterday and is due here on Tuesday next with general cargo from Antwerp and London.
The S.S. Trojan Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on the 8th inst, and is due at Alexandria on or about the 24th.
The Ellerman liner Fabian arrived yesterday from Liverpool and Malta with a general cargo.
The Ellerman liner Britannia arrived at Liverpool yesterday morning.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
FOOTBALL
EGYPTIAN SHIELD.
KOSB v R DUBLIN FUSILIERS
div.p: Over three thousand enthusiastic spectators —mostly military—watched the football match yesterday afternoon at the Sporting Club, which displayed quite an unwanted scene of animation, who rein the tartan kilt and glen-garry showed to g rod advantage—f-r there were between two and three hundred of the Borderers from Cairo among the throng. The Borderers kicked off with the wind in their faces, and despite their determined efforts, they were overplayed by th« Dublin Fusiliers, who scored three in the first half. There goals were scored by Dowling. Alton, and O'Dunnell. Despite their energies in the first half the Irishmeu kept up with a wonderful enthusiasm, and carried all before them, O'Donnell scoring the fourth goal by a magnificent run the whole length of the field, lo the first half Wood had rooted a penalty goal for the Borderers, the Dabs thus winning by 4 goals to 1.

div.head: OPENING OF THE SEMIRAMIS
div.p: The short account in yesterday's issue gave hot a very bald account of the festivities which celebrated the inauguration of the Semiramis Hotel. Although the huge building on the river bank has become a familiar landmark daring the last few months, there were but few who had folly realized its charm till nearer approach revealed its magnificence. The snow- white facade has only within the last few days received its final adornments of rates, etc., and on Thursday a multitude of flags hui g from every window and many plants and palms adorned its verandahs and windows.' Within, - the vestibule was charmingly furnished with chairs and tables, while a handsome buffet dispensed tea, etc., to those who chose 'he afternoon fir their first visit Workmen were still hard at work giving finishing touches in various directions, the ball room giving but scanty promise of the glories which greeted the ye at a later hour.

Some ninety guests assembled about 7.30 in response to the invitations to dinner issued to the leading official Many of those connected witht the hotel management were also present, and many others besides the English-speaking community graced the occassion. Bracale's band, which had played during the dinner hour, was augmented later on by the sextette and are long the newly-laid parquet floor which commenced by being somehwat stiff and heavy, was polished to the full by the eager feet of many dancers. In fact, the numbers became so great the when the evening was half over a certain few decided to move on to Ghezireh Palace for the reaminder og the evening, and as some of those at the latter hotel had also decided to spend part of their evening at the Semiramis there was a constant coming and going between the two hotels, and, as each ball-room had its full number of dancers, it may be computed that everyone in Cairo whose dancing days are not yet over was taking active exercise at either one or the other place.

It was past two o'clock before the last weary pleasure seekers left Ghezireh, and as they returned across the bridge to Cairo, the lights in the Semiramis were still ablaze to show festivities there had not yet drawn to their close.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lady Caroline Gordon Lennox and Lady - Helen Gordon Lennox, who arrived at the Savoy on Wednesday, have found Lady Muriel Beckwith happily convalescent. She is excited to be up and out again in a few days.

Lady Migenis, with Lady Winifred Corry and Miss Coery, have again returned to the. Savoy, after their trip to Upper Egypt ; and Lady Weatmaoott, with Mr. and Mrs. Bido Pavlowski, have also returned to their aid quarters.

Among other arrivals at the Savoy bar Thursday were the Count and Countess of Carnarvon, Earl Barto of Tatton, and the Duchess of Buckingham, Mr. and Mrs. Isidor Sitraos of New York, and Mr. and Mrs. Ed. Stanton Bayer, who also hail from the States. The Count and Counters Ponrtalès arrived last evening ; and M. and Mme Cordonier have left, as have the Baron and Baroness Pfyffer.
Lord and Lady Meath have arrived at Mena House Hotel
Prince Auguste d'Arenberg, president of the board of the Suez Canal Co., arrived yesterday mornig at Ismailieh by the steam launch Hirondelle.
Pierre Loti left the Savoy Hotel on Wednesday and has gone up the river in a private dahabeah.

THe Hon. Guy Wilson has also gone up the river, having only spent a couple of days in Cairo; and Count Zapary has started on his shooting expedition which will take him far into the Sudan and maybe in Abyssinia.
Major General Richard Henry Jeff, CMG, who with Mrs. Jeff, is at present is one of the few soldiers who have been recalled to service after retirement Promoted to the rank of

parents of various sons who have also shown themselves of exceptional ability. One is attached to the 60th Toyal Rufles. Another is on the staff of Sir Derzel Ihbetson, Leiut. Governor of the Punjab, and one is doing well in HM Navy; the youngest is now on the staff of the Agricultural Bank in Egypt.
Sad Fasha Zaghoul will visit the Cairo Coptic school on Monday

Mr. Ronald Storrs has been transferred from the Inspectorate of the Customs Administration at Alexandria to the office of the Financial Adviser at Cairo, in teh capacity of Assistant Financial Secretary.
M Procopins, portrait printer to the Negus Menelik, who is now in Alexandria, has resigned his position at the Ethiopian Court, and will reside here.

div.head:
USA AND JAPAN
STATEMENT BY PRESIDENT

div.p: President Roosevelt, in the course of an interview, stated that the published reports of his speech before the Californian Congressmen were without foundation. He never suggested the Japan ad presented an ultimatum nor that there was any danger of war. He rigorously deprecates as michevious and wicked the war talk which was utterly unjustified by the facts of the case.
It is stated here that the new treaty with Japan will possibly be presented to the Senate in March. (REUTER)

In the Chamber of Deputies, M. Jaurès criticized the maneuvers on the Bourse aiming at procuring money for Russia. M. Caillaux replied that French investments abroad gave diplomatic force to France. The simple order of the day was voted. {Havas)
A sharp fall in French Rentes took place here owing to the ambiguity of the income tax bill regarding them. (Reuter)

M. Alexandrowsky, the Governor of Pensa, and Comissioner of the Red Cross during the Japanese war, was assassinated whilst leaving the theatre. His assassin was severely wounded and has died in hospital. (Reuter)
Alexandrowsky, Governor of the city, has been assassinated. ( Havas)

The primary Elections have been proceeding during the past fortnight throughout Russia, hot it is impossible to arrive at anything resembling a correct classification. The Government and the Liberals alike maintain that each has secured the majority. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE THAWA TRIAL
PATHETIC SCENES IN COURT

div.p: Most pathetic scenes were witnessed at tin Thaw trial yesterday. The prisoner's wife, in giving evidence, told a terrible story of her betrayal by Stanford White. The prisoner, his wife, and nearly all the court wept. The evidence has changed the aspect of the case, showing a strong motive for the deed. (Reuter)
A boiler explosion on a torpedo boat caused the death of nine persons (Havas)
The King and Queen have had a quiet day and will return to England to-morrow (Reuter)

div.head:
LORDS AND COMMONS
PREPARING FOR THE FRAY

div.p: The Attorney General, speaking at Leeds, said that the fight with the Lords would be a tough job because it meant one or two discolutions and a combination of the Crown adn the people against the aristocracy.
The Unionist leaders challenge an appeal to the country against the Lords with the utmost confidence.
The Cabinet sat three days running, indicatigin special energy in the preparing for the Session. (Reuter)

The Press comments on the result oi the elections and the new grouping of parties in the Reichstag. Most of the newspapers recognize that the object of the dissolution has been attained and that Prince von Bulow has succeeded in combining the Clerical and Socialist majority. The Clericals are no longer strong enough to form an opposition majority with the assistance of the Socialists.

Although the number of Centri.t members has not diminished, they have no longer the same power since the check to the Socialists. The 'Vorwarts" even recognizes that Prince von Bulow is conqueror and has attained his object.

The newspapers reproduce the criticism of the foreign news on the subject of the Emperor's speech and unanimity refute to false commentaries which insist that His Majesty's words foretell an aggressive policy towards foreign countries. (Reuter)
Alien students, mainly Russian, who assisted the Socialists at the elections, have been notified to quit the country within a fortnight. (Reuter)
The Emporer has wired to the King of Saxony his lively satisfaction at the results of the elections. He was specially thankful that the people of Saxony had displayed a healthy patriotic sentiment.

div.head: REVUE COMERCIALE
Cotons.
div.p: Inoontsstablement le bean fays d'Egypto eat le véritable paya dps miracles et si nos voulions one nouvelle preove de cette exertion qui ne date pas d'aojoord'bui, nons t'avons qo' regarder ce que la spéculation a fait pendant cette semaine snr notre munbé cotonnier : Sans ancon motif plausible ponr l'appoyer, sans que rien de nouveau soit aorvenu ponr loi péter un conconrs qurlcon- qnr, tout au contraire, avec des raisins militant plntûten laveur delà buixe, elle est parvenue, non seulement h modifier l'allure faihle qoi se faisait remaïqxer en o Otnre de vendredi dernier mais aussi à punster les cours et à npus valoir une hausse qui, au point culminant, dépassait le 1 /St tallstil l/'est un véritable tour de force à son actif, mais le plus fuit est que le point de départ du mouvement auquel nous avons assisté était bâté sur des nouvelles fans ses, dénaturées on simplement mal in'erpié'ée». Que les brnits mis parfois en circulation fassent atteindre le but vité parles ii terrestres, cela n'a rien d'extraordinaire, quitte à réaciionner une fois le pot aux roses découvert; mais que, malgré l'expérience dn passé, il se trouve tou- - jours des geDS à notre corbeille en si grand f-nombre poor gober tout ce qu'on leur sert et sans se douuer U peine de coutiôler quoi que ce soit, cela dépasse toute oomprébeusion I Et pourtant c'est à un pareil speotaole qu'unofois de plis il nous a é'é donné d'a-sis- -, ter pendant la semaine qni vient de s'écouler, oar, après toot, le changement dans la tendance oonataté dans la matinée de Bamedi et la reprise qui a suivi, ainsi que l'aiceutuatiou de l'amélioration dans la journée de lundi n'avaient auoune raison d'Otreot u'ont é é que le résultat des deux canards lancés. Le premier a ooosisté dans l'annonce que le forwarded de la semaine pour les égyptiens était de 30/00 balles, chiffre qoi a été admis sans quo personne ait réfléchi qne ni le flottant, ni les importations de la semaine, ni la modification connue dans le stock, le tout à Liverpool, ne pouvaient le permettre ; mais fort heureusement que l't ffet qu'il a produit n'a eu qu'une courte durée, lea dépêches reçues do Liverpool par d'autres maiions ayant vite prouvé que dans l'espèce il n'y avait eu jeu qu'un simple zéro ajouté h la quaotité réelle qui était de

3.0 balles seulement. I.e mot supercherie a même été lancé,' mais pour notre part nous croyons qo'an fond il ne s'eat sgi que d'une -interprétation, influencée par l'intérêt personnel peut-être et qoi a fait penser que les 30.0 balles dévalent indiquer les retraits de la filature.

Quant à l'autre renseignement, auquel noos avons fait allusion, et qui n'était nullement vrai, c'est l'assertion que les achats de lundi matin faits par la spéculation, étalent pour compte do Commerce d'exportation.

Quoiqu'il en soit, les prix avaient lait dn chemin et la hausse, par la suite, a fini par trouver une certaine joitficatiun dare la tenue de Liverpool pour nos cotons. Il est vrai qu'il n'y avait ancun rapport entre nos ooors et ceux du gta.ud marché anglais, mais à la rigoeur la demande si inopinemeht. èurgie . pouvait être considérée comoJe étant un eymplûme encourageant et, dans tous les cas, comme une base plus raisonnée que les nouvelles propagées et que rieu ne prônait. égotons encore qu'aux racontars déjà mentionnés. on avait anssi joint l'affirmation, controuvée dénis, qu'il s'était formé nn syndicat pour recevoir le Mars et que l'une de nos plus puissantes maisons était à la tête de la combinaison.

Maintenant quant an résumé de tont ce qni précèdp, il se condense dans ceoi : Arrivé* à SI 38/38, les résiliations ont commencé hier, et avec la réduction constatée dans les exportations de la lésine ai jour- d'bui, la fermeté a vite fait place à la faiblesse et c Mme résultat n'aériez) c'est à 81 7/16 que le Mars finit définitivement ce soir. C'est encore bean, car il nous reste quand H ê in B un quart de tallari de hausse snr la cote de Vendredi dernier, mais en y regardant de près, on sajeiçoit de suite que la tendance, qoi semble sou tente, est au contraire très indécise et que n'il n'y a pas reprise dans les en barqui menls, un mouvement rétrograde est daus le domaine des probabilités.
Sous le ra| port de l'activité, il n'y a rieu à dire, elle a éé satisfaisante; toutefois, l'abstention delà filature est toujours pretqoe absolpe.

Bile l'a été pent être moins ear la nouvelle récolte, et c'est à cette raison que l'on pourrait attribuer la fermeté du Novembre à la suite de la part prise aux afftires comme acheteurs, mais là aussi ou nous uertifie qne les aobats de la filature ne sont que sporadqnea et pen importants, sans compter qu'ils sont limités an Continent.

On dit enbore, et nous reprodoiaons Viofor- mation sans eu assamer la responsabilité, qne la filature américaine aurait montré des velléités, par-ci, par-là, de revendre nn pen do vieux ooton qu'elle a acheté, ce qui tendrait à faire oroire, comme d'aucuns a'y attendaient, que le coton longue-soie commence à sortir de chez le oultivateur, et que s'il y a pénurie en CCB sortes de coton, il n'y a pas ce manque à un degré presque absolu qu'on affirmait.

Pour retouruer au Novembre, nons dirons que le cours do ce soir est de 18 19/32, eu hausse de 5/16 sur la clôture de la semaine passée, et que les dispositions de la spéonlation sont toujours belliqueuses. Pourvu quelle n'exagère pas ses mai couvres.

l,e seul fjpit réellement intéressant de la semaine est Te réveil de l'-Egyptien à Liverpool, mais l'énorme avantage offert par les oouradu dit marché eu comparaison des nOtrea, expliquent la préférence des acheteurs, qu'il s'agisse de personnes ayant à livrer, dea fi'a- teura anglais ou de demande ponr la réexportation.

L7 méricain a fini par booger à son tour et cette H morne nous avons en le plrisir de le voir monter assi z séiieirsement ; il n'en était que temps Les dernières dépêches de New- Yoik disent aussi qne la spéculation commence à dernier signe ae vie, qoe le marché s'élargit et que tont promet des affaires pins suivies d'ioi peu. Noos en acceptons 1'augnre, mais ce qni semble tempérer l'espoir qne l'on ressent à la lecture de ces nouvelles, o'est la question du mouvoment de la récolte qui, quoique se ralentissant, est toujours formidable et de nature à faire adopter les estimations les plus fortes qu'on ait lancées an sujet du renden eut probable de la récolte. Fort heureusement que la filature est engagée et trouve sa convenance à continuer tes aohate anx prix aotuels.

Chei nous aussi le mouvement de la récolte est fort : nons sommes déjà à 6.000.000 de oantars de reoettes, et depuis que'qnea jours il y a recrudescence dans les arrivages, oe qui fait de nouveau pencher les idées vers les 7.000.000 de oantars ooinme récolte. Du reste, si à la quantité déjà nç :e ou ajoute la reotifi oation pour ainsi dire habituelle dé fin d'année qni est de 50.C00 oantars environ, oe qui nous viendra du Soudan, Sonakim, Tokar et Om dnrman et qni est estimé oette année an moins à 70.000 anars, ainsi q ie oe qui pourrait nous venir de la Haote-Egypte en août en fait de coton nouveau, on atteindrait déjà on total de près de 6.2000 cantars, et il est certain qoe oe n'est pas aveo des données pareilles que l'on pourrait soutenir que la ré coite ne saurait dépasser de beaucoup les 6 500.000 cantava. Ceux qoi préconisent on rendement aussi limité, laissent peroer le boot de l'oreille, tont anssi bien que ceux qoi préteudent que les veDtes à la filature atteignent déjà 6.000.000 de cantars. Certes on pent jongler toujours aveo la question des chiffres, mais noua serions curieux de voir de quelle façon ils se tireraieut d'embarras ceux qui s'amusent à lancer des affirmations un peu trop bàtives, le joor i h ils auraient à s'expliquer devant leurs clients I

Le marché do disponible a en une on deux journées d'animation, mais aveo la hausse do ces jours derniers, les acheteurs sont de nou veau tiès réserves. Il est de fait que les sff»i res sont plus réduites, tant pour les exporta tours que ponr les arbitragiates.

Poor ce qui est des prix, ce ne sont que les i Mit Affifi qui ont avancé de 3/8 ponr le Good fair et de 1/2 tallari ponr les au ne* classements. Dans les Abassi et lea Jiannovich, ce ne sont qoe les extras qui profitent de 1/8 d'améliora tion, tandis qne lea provenances Haute-Egypte et Fayoumi, négligées à causa dé leur trop seu sible rapprochement do Mit Affifi, et par conséquent, plus facilement offertes sur le marché, restant sans auonn changement d'aptès la oote offioielle. Aveo un élargissement de l'éoart aotuel, les aohetears y reviendraient probablement.

Les exportations de la semaine sont restées inférieures anx prévisions de 8.000 Balles envi roo, leur total n'étant qae de 23.000 Balles, oontre 20 000 eu 1906. C'est mieox que l'année dernière, mais ce qui a impressionné le pnblio de la oorbeille o'est la chute rapide en oompa raison des mois précédents. Toutefois, si la semaine reste isolée, le fait serait sans oonsé- queaces, mais ce qne l'on semble redouter le plus, b'est la comparaison des chiffres ponr la semaine prochaine, l'ani.ée dernière devant se présenter aveo 33.000 Balles. Il est encore trop tot iour faire des prouostios, mais nous orai- gnons fort qoe l'avantage soit loin d'être en faveur de l'année courante.

Liverpool a été on ne pent plus favorable anx Egyptiens et comme ventes et oomme prix. Eu tons cas, l'avantage récolté poor la semaine est de 1/4 de bansse snr le spot qne nous trouvons à 10 11/16 et de 19/64 ponr les futurs Mars cotés à 10 34/64.

Lea Américains an fond n'ont pas été très actifs, mais quand même les vente* ne sont pas msnvsises comme ensemble. Pour qni con- cérne les prix, par contre, il y a avance sensible, Boit 22 points snr le spot qui est à 6.09, 20 pour le Mars-Avril coté à 5.69 et 16 poor le Juillet-Ar-Û' qui clôture à 5-'9.
GRAINES DE COTON

LOS arrivages, en diminution depuis quelque temps, ont à peine suffi aux besoins de l'exportation, et o'est naturellement surtout à Mtte circonstance que l'on doit la fermeté du disponib'e qui, malgré la baisse des contrats et les nouvelles du dehors, n'a pas fléchi an dessous de P.T. 73.
Comme tendance, il reste ferme, car pour la semaine prochaine aussi il y aura des exportations assez conséquentes.

En ooutrats. les affaires sont très limitées depuis qne'qnes jours, la spéculation ne montrant guère de l'in'éiôt à l'article. Quant anx prix, ils sont en baisse et le Février Mars finit à P.T. 74, soit 1 1/4 de moins qne la olôture de la semaine dernière.

Hull à payé de £ 7 à 7 2/6, mais l'on prétend qne MS aobats sont rimplement spéculatifs, la fabrique ae tenant à l'éoart. Dn reste, elle est amplement fournie ponr les mois rapprochés, tandis que ponr les éloigné* elle donne la préférence à la graine de Bombay qui, achetable à £ L 13/6 an-ldessous de la nôtre, lai laisse une marge réelle et effective pour la vente des tourteaux. Bombay va sûrement nous jouer un mauvais tonr.
La France ae tient à l'écart et ne rentrerait dans l'article qu'en cas de baisse. Trieste, par contre, demande à acheter.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: La semaine qui viont de finir a été oons tciée pre-tjne exclusivement anx Agrioole, Ri z et Splendid Hotels. Nile Land, Nongovioh Hotels, United Lands et Arditi.
Tontes MS valeurs sont en hansse. la plu- pnrt d'entre elles à cause de la plus valce énorme des terrains.

La Nile Laod bé"éfio:a de £ 4 1/8 à 23 1/8, les Nongovioh de £ 2 13/16 à 25 7/-*. les Riiz do demi-livre à 2 1/8, et les Splendid Hotels de 9/16 à 4 9/16 ; l'Uuited et l'Arditi gagnent 1/16 anxoonts respectifs de 1 5/16 et 1 7/16. De gros paquets d'Agrioole ont été échangés entre 9 7/8 et 10, prix auquel on olôture vendeurs.

L'attention du marché ayant été tonte entière absorbée par les titres ci-dessus, le reste de la oote a partiellement souffert de la [ négligence de la spéonlation. C'est ainsi que I snr une soixantaine de valeurs inscrites à la oote offioielle de notre bourse, la moitié environ sont en baisse, une quii saine seulement en j bansse, et les autres demeurent stationnaires.
A part les gains déjà signalés, une hausse de 5 francs sur l'obligation Crédit Foncier à 3 45 et de 1/8 scr l'Uuiou Foncière à 6 3/8, les autrei améliorations sont insignifiantes

En baisse il nons tant signaler les Dividendes Tramways qui perdent 6 fr. à 369, les Jouis- »anoes Erex du Caire 9 fr. à 289, la Cassa di Sannto 4 fr. à 280 l'ancienne et 274 la nouvelle, la Dsferred Delta 1/4 à 12 3/4. la Delta Laud 1/4 à 4 6/16, l'Urbaine 7/16 à 7 7/16, l'aotion Comptoir 1/2 à 7 7/16, et la fondateur 2 livres à 92.

Telle eet dans ses grandes lignes la situation i de notre marché. C'est à la lenteur de la détente monétaire et au drainage opéré par lee nouvelles .émissions que nons devons le retard de la campagne annuelle de hausse ; mais oette oampague elle même, eu dépit de tous les obstacles, semble inévitable, tant à oause de la déprédation actuelle d'an grand nombre d'exoellents titres qne do l'affl ix pro- . ohain de oapitaox considérables snr notre place. 1 A Paris et à Londre-, la situation s'éolairoit graduellement:, la rente française avanoe à 95.67 et la réserve de la Banque d'Angleterre est portée à 49 5/8, soit une progression de 1 1/4%. Le taux privé d'esoompte fluotuo à obhque iustant de 4 5/8 à 4 3/4 % et inversement. Mais, s'il faut eu croire do hautes personnalités financières, il n'y a plus à oraindre pour le moment de resserrement monétaire.
Après la hausse des terrains au Caire, nons en avons une analogue à Alexandrie, mais
plu» lento et oins raisonné» Q p'quos rfftires déji et d'antres en cours s-mbleut démontrer que Pimpolsion est définitivement donnée.

Le Comptoir Financier et Comme'oiil d'Egypte a nrboé à la Sncié é d'Entreprisps Urbaines et Rurales l'ancien imrop' blo» de la Compagnie dn Guz an prix dp £ 31,000 U s'agit d'one étendue de 1400 pio; mais, 350 pica étant occupés par dê* ruelles, la surface ntili*ab!e se troove ainsi réduite à 1050 pice. Dans ces oorid tions le pic revient à près de 30 livre», chiffre qui met en évidence le mouvement, rapide de hausse que suivent les terrains de notre ville. Le lendemain même de la conclusion do l'uffiire, le Comptoir reopvait une offre ferme qni lui laissait 4000 livres de béi'éfi :e. L'immeuble nue fois restauré rervira de bureaux poor le Comptoir Financier ; des constructions seront ajoutées SUT l'arrière du bû'iinent ; quant aux magasios, ils constitue rout de magn fiques oavsanx poor la sooié'é.
Il nous revient que l'Urbaine aurait aussi vendu le terrain avoisinant, oooupé par les magasins Borman ; mais les détails né sont pas encore oonnus. I

Las Ritz Hotels sont en pourparlers pour l'aohat aux Splendid du New Khédivial Hotel. D'après la rumeur en circulation, l'échange se ferait sur la base de 5 livres par action Splendid, soit en numéraire, soit eu actions Ri'z Hotels. Bu oe qui nous conceruo, nous oroyons oette estimation da U valeur des 8plendid bien au-dessous de la réalité, oar, en prenant pour base le prix que M. Bacos a payé le terrain avoisiuaut du Z zinis, soit 11 livres le pio, le terrain seul du New Kbedivial Hotel vant £ 70,000 ; ai l'on ajoute à oe obiffre £ f0,000 pour la valeor de l'immeuble loe qui n'a rien dVxagéré, Ja société ayant payé plus de £20 (H'O les simples additions récemment faites), £ 10,000 de fonds de roulement, £ 6,000 de réserve et £ 1,500 de coupon non distriboé, on arrive au total de £146 500. Le nombre d'actions étant de 22.600, la valeur iutriiiièque de obsenne, établie sur ces données, serait ainsi de plus de 6 livres.

Les actionnaires des Cotton Mills se sont rénnia le 5 courant poor délibérer sur l'avenir do la société II a été décidé, dans cette assem bléo, de procéder à la liquidation, si le gouvernement persista à exiger le droit d'accises, comme il l'a fait jmqn'ioi. Au oas où il.y renoncerait en vue d'encourager l'industrie locale, on étudierait dans nne réunion ivftë- rienro la meilleur moyen de reconstituer l'affaire sur dos base* solides.' On vendrait' probablement l'empkcement oooupé actuellement par l'immeuble de la sooié'.é pour en construire soantre snr nn terrain meilleur marahé et tur des données eolnarque
lia Lnnghis, dont l'émission a en lieu oes jnnroi. a obten i nn grand Huooèi. La souscription ayant é oonvsrte 12 fais on a fermé les guiohets nvant le délai oo-ivenu.

Parmi le* nouvelles sroé'é* en oonrs de formation se trouve The Industrial, Building, and Cnmm-rnial Company of Ezypt, Ltd, au api'al de £ 4' 0,060, divné en 499,375 aotions de £ 1 et 12,500 parts de fondateur de 1 shelling. Il s'agit .d'exploiter lea gisements de gypre découverts an Mariout.—MM. Patea et Wenger, agents de ohange au Caire, vont prochainement transformer lenr agence en société anonyme sous le nom de Omnium Financial Cempai y.

The Bourse and Exchange (Arditi) qui a été soumise arjmrd'hni an ballottage poor sou admission dans la corbeille des valeurs a été admise à Panât imité Demain a lieu le ballottage pour son admission daus la oorbeille dea marchandises. L'estime dont jouissent MM. Arditi sar notre place est ou garant qne la proposition aura le nême succès.

NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, Vendredi 8 Février 1907. Le taux de l'escompte libre h Londres est resté hier à 4 S pour oeut. Au Stook Exchaiigr, le Consolidé anglais s'est maintenu à 87 1/8 et Taudifiés à 10S 8/4. La National Bank a gagné 1/8 à 98 3/8. L'Âgrioole est renseignés k 10 La Daïra a perdu 1/8 k 17 3/4. La Delta Light est demeurée iuohangée à 11 1/2.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a progressé de 1 frano k 778. La Banque d'Athènes a rétrogradé de 2 francs k 135.

loi, le mtrohé des valeurs a présenté plan ou moins la mfi-ne physionomie qn'bior. Allure géoérale ferme, aveo tsndanoe k l'amélioration, mais affaires restreintes. L'animation s'est concentrée dans U section dos hôtels, où les transactions ont été nombreuses.

Dans le oompsrtimeDt des Banques, la Na tional aaraocé k 28 1/8. L'Xgrioolas's-c tassés k 10 ; sa part de fondateur est moutés k £ 970. La Cassa di Somto sst revenue k 79. Le Comptoir Finanoier a faibli k 7 1/2 Lss parts de fondateur Sooié'é Générale Egyptisnue ont été ootésa 100 francs.

Le Crédit Foncier est res'é à 774 ; l'obligation k lote ancienne a progressé à 346-347. lia Dxïré s'est raffermis a 17 5/8 et U Nile Lind a 23 1/8. L'B iterpriee and Development a molli a 13 13/16 et sa part a 22 1/4.

Les Entreprises Imtnobil ères e' Travaux ont été ramenées a 13 et leur part a 260. L'Epargne Immobilière e*t restée a 3 3/8 ; sa part a c'ô taré a 240. L'Bxpreas Ni'e a progressé a 6 1/32 et'sa part a 340.

Ho bonne tenue, la Suburban (Demordacho) a àvanoéa 6 1/16 ponr les raisons que nous avorta déjà exjoBéîs dans notre Ciroulairo dn 18 Janvier dernier. La Société Egyptienne de Fublioité a été demandée a 4 3/4.

bans le groupe des valeurs hôtelière9, los Nnngoviob, très mouvementés, ont encore '-'g^gué près de 3/8 a 25 15/16-26, bien que la vente do Savoy Hotel n'ait point été confirmée. ( /Lee Egyptian ont été bien tenus a 12 3/4-13/16. Les ExoeLior ont avancé a 4 ll/l6^Cette 'j bonne tendance s'explique par le tait de / l'approche de l'assemblée extraordinaire convoquée poor le 12 dn courant. On assure que le projet b x >rrè de liquidation est appe'é a être écarté définitivement ; tout an contraire, il faudrait s'attendre, môme en oaa de vente dn terrain dn sqnare Soliman Pacha, a l'augmentation dn oapital social et a la mise a exécution dn plan rationnel consistant a remplir le programme de la Sooiété, o'est-a dire a s'occuper de la oréation d'hô'els la où le besoin s'en fait sentir dans le paya. Les National se sont maintenus a leur prix d'hier ; il y a lien de prévoir on mouvement sur ce titre par mite de l'ordre dn joorde l'assemblée extraordinaire qui sera tenue le 13 do courant. Les Ritx Hotels ont avancé a 2 3/16 et les Splendid Hotels a 4 5/8 sur la réédition de la rnménr suivant laquelle une fusion se négocierait entre ose deux Booiétés.

Patmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land s'est teane k 4 3/8; la nomination des deux administrateurs nouveaux dn Board local de la 8ociété a été renvoyée k la semaine prochaine. Les Abdy sont restés k l-5/16-3/8. les New Bgyptian ont o'-ôtnré a 30 sb. 3 et les Hooker a l 1/8-3/16. Lss United Lands ont progressé a 1 5/16 et leur part a 10.

Nous croyons savoir que le dividende de l'Agricoltarsd Bank of Egypt ponr l'exercice éoonlé sera de 9 ahallioga (contre 7 sh. 6 ponr l'exiroioe préoéient) par action de oapital et de £49. 15 sb. par part de fontatenr.
D'antre part, si nos informations sont exaotes, le dividenle de la National Ba k of Egypt sera de 13 shellings ooutre 16 ponr l'exeroioe préoédent.
Nous détachons d'nno de nov. oorreepjnda i- oes de Londres, en date du 1er Février, le passage suivant:

" Le marché monétaire oontinno a s'améliorer. Les Banques ont demandé de 5 1/4 » 6 pour sent pour leors avarices au Stock Ex- l ohange, aveo marge poor les reporta jniqu'a mi-Février ; les taox de la précédente liquidation étaient de 6 l/l a 7 ponr'cent. Aujourd'hui les Consolidés ont été reportés sotte 4 1/2 et 5 poor oent jnBqu'a fin Février.

div.head: ONLY WORK ON ANGLO EGYPTAIN SUDAN
REISSUE JUST OUT
containing
An Orographical Map of the whole Nile Basin.
OUR SUDAN.
div.p: By John Ward, FSA
Author of "Egypt, its Pyramids and Progress"
Dedicated by Request to
Lord Kitchener of Khartoum
Crown 4tc 400pp. 720 Illustrations
Price: 21s. net
Letter from Sir Rudolph von Slatin

Dear Mr Ward- Your delightfil and most interesting book on the Soudan has reached me. I congratulate you on heartily on the excellent manner in which the work is written adn illustrated. All of us who have done our little best to regenerate the country, after its terrible misfortunes, have recieved more than kind treatment at your hands... I don't suppose anyone realises mroe than I do the change that has come over Sudan since my old and tyrannical master Khalifa disappeared from teh scene. Your depiction of the Peace and PRogress is in fqact a sequel to my Fire adn Sword in Sudan
With kindest regards believe me,
Yours sincerely,
